metadata.description: Common Python errors with student-friendly explanations and solutions

SyntaxError.analogy: Like forgetting punctuation in a sentence - Python needs proper 'grammar' too!
commonCauses: Incorrect indentation (Python is picky about spaces)
recognitionPatterns: SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
SyntaxError.studentExplanation: Python is like a very picky English teacher - it needs perfect 'grammar' (syntax) to understand your code. Don't worry, the error message tells you exactly where the problem is!
immediateHelp: ðŸ” Look at the line number in the error message
ðŸ” Check for missing colons (:) at the end of if/for/while lines
ðŸ” Count your opening and closing parentheses/quotes
ðŸ” Make sure indentation is consistent (use same number of spaces)

example.explanation: Python needs a colon (:) to know where the condition ends and the action begins
Every opening quote needs a matching closing quote
Functions in Python need parentheses, even if they're empty

preventionTips: Use a code editor that highlights matching brackets/quotes
Write one line at a time and test frequently
Read your code out loud - missing punctuation often 'sounds' wrong

NameError.analogy: Like trying to call someone whose number isn't in your phone contacts yet!
commonCauses: Using a variable before defining it
recognitionPatterns: NameError: global name '...' is not defined
NameError.studentExplanation: Python doesn't recognize the variable name you're trying to use. It's like trying to text someone who isn't in your contacts - you need to add them first!
immediateHelp: ðŸ” Check if you created the variable before using it
ðŸ” Look for typos in the variable name
ðŸ” Make sure capitalization matches exactly
ðŸ” Verify you're using the variable in the right place

example.explanation: You must create (assign) a variable before you can use it
Variable names must match exactly - Python sees 'my_name' and 'myname' as completely different

preventionTips: Use descriptive variable names that are hard to misspell
Define all variables at the top of your program when possible
Use consistent naming conventions (snake_case or camelCase)

TypeError.analogy: Like trying to add apples + oranges - they're both fruit, but you can't do math with different types!
commonCauses: Trying to do math with strings (text)
Concatenating strings and numbers without conversion
Using wrong operations for data types
Forgetting to convert input() to numbers
recognitionPatterns: TypeError: can't multiply sequence by non-int
TypeError: must be str, not int
TypeError.studentExplanation: You're trying to do something with the wrong type of data. It's like trying to do math with words - Python needs numbers for math and text for text operations!
immediateHelp: ðŸ” Check if you're doing math with text (strings)
ðŸ” Remember: input() always gives you text, even if user types numbers
ðŸ” Use int() or float() to convert text to numbers
ðŸ” Use str() to convert numbers to text

example.explanation: input() gives you text ('18'), but you need a number (18) for math
To combine text and numbers, convert the number to text first

preventionTips: Always convert input() to the right type immediately
Use f-strings for mixing text and numbers: f'Age: {age}'
Think about what type of data each variable should hold

IndentationError.analogy: Like paragraphs in an essay - Python uses indentation to understand which code belongs together!
commonCauses: Extra indentation where none is needed
recognitionPatterns: IndentationError: unindent does not match any outer indentation level
IndentationError.studentExplanation: Python uses indentation (spacing) like paragraphs in an essay to understand which code belongs together. Everything inside an if/for/while block needs to be indented the same amount!
immediateHelp: ðŸ” Make sure code inside if/for/while blocks is indented
ðŸ” Use exactly 4 spaces for each level of indentation
ðŸ” Don't mix tabs and spaces - pick one and stick with it
ðŸ” Make sure all lines at the same level have the same indentation

example.explanation: Code inside the if block must be indented (usually 4 spaces)
All lines at the same level must have exactly the same indentation

preventionTips: Set your editor to show spaces/tabs visually
Configure your editor to use 4 spaces for indentation
Be consistent - if you start with spaces, always use spaces

immediateHelp.action: Show targeted error explanation and hint
